Correct
That’s right! Sebaceous glands are distributed over most of body surface and are influenced by circulating hormones. Hypersecretion of sebaceous glands can block follicles contributing to acne.

gfhdfghfh.png

As mentioned earlier with hair, sebaceous glands are distributed over most of the body, except in the thick skin of the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. The duct usually opens into the upper part of a hair follicle. 
A hair follicle with its sebaceous gland and arrector pili muscle is called a pilosebaceous unit. Hair follicles, and therefore sebaceous glands, are particularly dense in the face and scalp. 
Sebaceous ducts open directly at the skin surface in certain hairless regions, inc. the glans penis, clitoris, eyelids and nipples
Acne vulgaris
INFO
Chronic inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit, commonly occur during adolescence in response to hormone changes at puberty.

Accelerated keratinization in the follicle combined with hypersecretion of the sebaceous gland causes accumulation of sebum within a blocked follicle. Anaerobic bacteria flourish, causing a localized inflammatory response.
This condition can be treated with systemic antibiotics and topical steroids.
